author: risa yamada
text: unlike in recent star trek iterations, which are mostly peaceful and pc, anything alien on the original show was usually phaser fodder. true to the shatner school of diplomacy, interplay's star trek: starfleet command is a tense game of real-time tactical combat based on the '80s board game starfleet battles (remembered fondly by hardcore gamers for the thickness of its rule book). players can employ all the desperate, last-ditch, jury-rigged tactics used by captain kirk long before macgyver popularized ad hoc ingenuity. in addition to batteries of phasers and photon torpedoes, you can jam the enemy's sensors, drop explosive mines, shove hostile ships into asteroids with tractor beams, or board opposing vessels via transporters.the game doesn't force you to wear the white hat of the united federation of planets either. several alien races from both the original tv show and the board game are available, each with military idiosyncrasies. the romulans have their famed cloaking device; the war-bent klingons have a penchant for antimatter-tipped homing missiles and rear-mounted weapons.every explosion in starfleet command is a cosmic event, with rippling shock waves lighting the void of space like flattened mushroom clouds. mercifully, battles are restricted to a 2-d plane (true 3-d space combat at this level of detail would be nightmarish rather than fun). massively complex and admirably faithful to its board game predecessor, this is a game that will overwhelm the casual player. but for veteran gamers and rabid star trek fans, starfleet command is the best and most thorough star trek experience available for the pc.star trek: starfleet command: $44.95. interplay: www.interplay.com.street credroom serviceorganize in stereoa time to gromany unhappy returnsthe wrath of youking of lost vegastouchscreens are betterurban legendmusicjust outta betareadmehere to reternitynatural selectionexquisite computingno village idiothigh dramacontributors
